poem:
Title: "The Morning After Judgment"

Amidst a dawn singing justice, a gavel echoed, loud and stern,
"Not a victim", chided the judge, his gaze firm.
Wheels of protests turned, cowbells' fury unleashed,
Whistles blowing, drowning the accused's breached speech.
A sign cried out to imprison, amidst the tumult's bittersweet cup,
The clamor of truth and justice, never to be hushed up.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘You’re not a victim’, judge tells ex-Trump aide Peter Navarro at sentencing for contempt of Congress – live 6.50pm GMT As Navarro was delivering remarks to reporters, a group of protesters clanged cow bells and used whistles to drown him out. One demonstrator held a sign, reading: “Lock Him Up”. Others chanted, “Liar,” as Navarro spoke. People from Navarro’s team attempted to quiet protestors, but to no avail. The whistle and the cowbell drown out". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
